8. Physics¶

This section contains the basic mathematical underpinnings used in our analysis of the basic DIY spectroscope.

The optical sign conventions used here follow Schroeder’s (1987) “Cartesian” approach. The plane for the optics (“lens/mirror surfaces”) are in the XY plane, the optical axis follows the Z axis. Along the Z axis, rays pass from the negative (lesser) to right (greater). Reflections reverse the sign. (I.e.: photons move in the positive direction along the Z axis.)

There are at least 6 dispersion techniques to consider:

    1. Fresnel (nearfield),

    1. Fraunhofer (slit) diffraction,

    1. Reflection and transmission diffraction gratings,

    1. Prisms and a grism (combination prism/transmission grating).

A lot of the mathematical manipulations used here are accessible via the Wolfram Alpha web site , freely accessible and with paid subscriptions.

8.1. BOTE Computation¶

To assist with basic design and to develop intuition, “Back of The Envelope” BOTE computation is in order. Astronomers utilize the “Centimeter Gram Seconds” (CGS) system. Here are a few guide pointers:

  1. Use the same units, here centimeters;

    • \(5 \times 10^{-5}\) cm for green light. \(5 \times 10^{-5}\) cm for blue and \(6 \times 10^{-5}\) cm for red. We use 300 and 600 l/mm gratings and the math cancels!

    • Translate grating \(l/mm\; to\l\) \(l/cm\)

  2. Remember sign conventions, and get the right equation.

  3. Follow the general spectrograph equation chain. Slit/grating/sensor.

8.2. Light¶

A wavelength is a cycle, its length is a function of the energy of the associated photon. An image has a ‘wavefront’ and that wavefront has a quality, expressed in fractions of a wavelength (variation of 1/10th of a wavelength \(2\times\pi/10 = 0.328\) (360 degrees for a full cycle) amounts to a shift of around 36 degrees! A lot of error. Using a ‘folding’ mirror mirror;folding adds error. This same wavefront error seeps in with irregular coatings and lens surfaces. It creeps in with the parallelism agreement between the front and back of a lens; with the co-alignment of lenses; and with the flatness of a grating’s plane.

8.3. The Behavior of Lenses¶

In theory, lenses work well. In practice there is the issue of the agreement between the curve at the front of the lens and that at the back of the lens (a wedge or a prism-astigmatism effect). The distance between a surface at the edge adds additional chances for dispersion of the light as it passes through the lens. The cheaper the lens the more likely the lens has issues.

Glass refracts, deferentially, as a function of energy (wavelength).

8.4. Lens Makers Equation¶

The general form of the lens makers equation:

\[\frac{1}{f} = (n-1) \left[ \frac{1}{R_1} - \frac{1}{R_2} + \frac{(n-1)d}{n R_1 R_2} \right]\]

where:

  • \(n\) is the index of refraction,

  • \(f\) the lens’ focal lengths,

  • \(R_1\) is the radius of curvature of the surface towards the object,

  • \(R_2\) is the radius of curvature of the surface towards the sensor, and

  • \(d\) is the thickness of the lens

See Wikipedia’s Lens Makers Equation.

Thin Lens Equation:

In practice the thin lens equation:

(1)¶\[\frac{1}{f} = \frac{1}{S_1} + \frac{1}{S_2}\]

8.5. Snell’s Law¶

\[\frac{\sin\theta_2}{\sin\theta_1} = \frac{n_1}{n_2} =\frac{v_2}{v_1}\]

Using the Shott Pocket Catalog

A point source (star) receives information from the entire aperture with a slight distortion due to its off-axis relationship. For spectroscopy, careful centering and alignment of the ‘target’ position on the slit onto a co-aligned optical axis keeps the noise symmetric. Off-axis star means asymmetric line profiles at the sensor. Slight, but there.

In considering the OVIO slit with a beam consisting a pencil of rays (bundle of rays – each with a different approach angle to the surface). Using the above equations it is easy to see that the f/ratio is altered significantly as each ray enters, passes, and exits the slit’s substrate. There is a condition where internal reflection adds an additional ray with changed geometry. This amounts to noise in the system. It is not a true caustic.

8.7. Grating Equation¶

(2)¶\[\frac{m\lambda}{d} = sin(\alpha) \pm sin(\beta)\]

where \(\lambda\) is the wavelength, \(\alpha\) is the angle of incidence, \(\beta\) is the diffracted angle (the dependent variable of real interest). The sign \(\pm\) is positive for reflection gratings and negative for transmission grating. The angle \(\phi = |\alpha| + |\beta|\) defines the main geometry of the system.

8.8. Spot Size and Slit Selection¶

In practice, the focal length drives the platescale eq: (3) and aperture drives resolution (4).

In general, the spot-size is independent of the aperture, and wholly dependent on the focal length. Since f/ratio is a derived value – equation eq: (3) bypasses the aperture and gives a result as a fraction of an arcsecond per micron at the focal plane:

(3)¶\[\frac{206204.8}{fl\times 1000} = \frac{x^"}{1 \mu{m}}\]

This is a elementary school ratio problem: where \(206204.8\) is the number of arc-seconds in a radian; \(fl\) is the focal length in mm (traditionally stated) and multiplied by 1000 to turn into microns; \(x^"\) is “x” in arc-seconds; the goal of \(1 \mu{m}\) relates to both pixel size and slit width.

In spectroscopy, the Rayleigh equation eq: (4) provides a critical estimate of the ability to separate the light from two close objects.

(4)¶\[\theta = 1.22\;\frac{\lambda}{D}\]

where \(\theta\) is the resolution IN RADIANS; \(1.22\) is the first Bessel J coefficient; \(\lambda\) is the wavelength in units of D; and \(D\) is the diameter of the aperture. For back-of-the-envelope estimates, use 5e-5 (\(5\times 10^{-5}\)) as the wavelength in [cm] and express D in matching units [cm].

Observation: The width of the slit dominates resolution within the spectroscope. The aperture requirement stresses the need for flux over resolution. A short focal length stresses the need for a small “spot size”, allowing a smaller slit width; in turn driving higher resolution.

The so-called ‘diffraction limited’ requirement of one arcsecond for stations deep in the atmosphere only requires an aperture of around 12.58 cm (4.95 inches). This is all that is satisfy most amateur needs under above average seeing conditions.

8.9. Sellmeier Equation¶

The Sellmeier Equation, uses an empirical equation to model the dispersion of light in medium with a given refractive index.

Values may be found at [Polyanskiy-2021]: Refractive Index Database

(5)¶\[n^2(\lambda) = 1 + \sum_i \frac{B_i \lambda^2}{\lambda^2 - C_i}\]

In practice, a small handful of empirical constants determines a workable solution to path-times for lenses:

(6)¶\[\lambda = 1 + \frac{B_1 \lambda^2 }{ \lambda^2 - C_1} + \frac{B_2 \lambda^2 }{ \lambda^2 - C_2} + \frac{B_3 \lambda^2 }{ \lambda^2 - C_3}\]

Coefficients may be had from several sources:

B_1

1.03961212

B_2

0.231792344

B_3

1.01046945

C_1

6.00069867 x 10^ 3 microns

C_2

2.00179144 x 10^-2 microns

C_3

1.03560653 x 10^ 2 microns

8.10. Scattering¶

In optical spectroscopy the wavelength ranges from 3300-12,000 Angstroms or .33 to 1.2 microns. Particles or defects in the optics may be modeled by \sigma = 2\pi\r/\lambda. Rayleigh scattering occurs when \sigma << 1 and \sigma << \lambda/10.

(7)¶\[I &= I_0 \frac{ 1+\cos^2 \theta }{2 R^2} \left( \frac{ 2 \pi }{ \lambda } \right)^4 \left( \frac{ n^2-1}{ n^2+2 } \right)^2 \left( \frac{d}{2} \right)^6\]

<ref>Seinfeld, John H. and Pandis, Spyros N. (2006) ‘’Atmospheric Chemistry and Physics, 2nd Edition’’, John Wiley and Sons, New Jersey, Chapter 15.1.1, {{ISBN|0471720186}}</ref>

(8)¶\[\sigma_\text{s} &= \frac{ 2 \pi^5}{3} \frac{d^6}{\lambda^4} \left( \frac{ n^2-1}{ n^2+2 } \right)^2\]

Siegel, R., Howell, J.R., (2002). [https://cds.cern.ch/record/1505325/files/9781439805336_TOC.pdf ''Thermal radiation heat transfer'']. p. 480. New York, NY: Taylor & Francis. {{ISBN|1560329688}}

8.11. Lambertian Reflection:¶

One calibration lamp method involves flooding the guider/slit chamber with light from an off-axis lamp. Experiments (Rodda/Yeager) showed variation in lamp placement had a significant impact in calibration line placement on the spectrum. Here is the simple case of light from a bulb radiating outwards. If the lamp is replaced with a patch of the reflecting area inside the chamber; and considering all contributions from the entire area of the chamber – it is easy to see where the off-axis contributions originate. 8.12. Thermal Expansion¶

In general the degree of thermal expansion is \(\propto\) inverse of the melting point. In practice the ODE

(10)¶\[\alpha_{L} = \frac{1}{L}\; \frac{\mathbf{d}L}{\mathbf{d}T}\]

where \(L\) is the length \(T\) is in units of temperature. FlexSpec 1 uses MKS, so coefficients here are in \(\mu{m}/m/K\).
